Award.AwardTitle: Boise State University Noyce II: Trajectory to Teaching from Recruiting to Career

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Phase II project is supporting a total of 75 Noyce scholars to become science and mathematics teachers. Boise State University is partnering with the Caldwell, Vallivue, Nampa, Joint No.2 School Districts and the Independent School District of Boise City. The project is providing summer internships to spark STEM undergraduate majors interest in STEM teaching as a career, providing scholarships for students completing their teacher preparation curriculum, and sustaining ongoing professional development to assure Noyce alumni success. Noyce alumni are being provided with opportunities to attend professional conferences, tuition assistance for continuing education, peer mentoring, and access to communities of practice. These project activities are accompanied by a rigorous plan of research that looks at factors that influence the multiple stages of STEM teacher education. Building on the Noyce I results with mathematics education, this project is also exploring the influence that Co-PIs from chemistry and engineering have on the number of physical science education majors graduating from Boise State.

The project is providing a model for holistically approaching the multiple stages of teacher preparation and development. The research and instrument development are expected to provide both a framework and the tools necessary to investigate the effectiveness of similar programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Boise State University Noyce II: Trajectory to Teaching From Recruiting to Career

    The goal of Boise State University’s Noyce II: Trajectory to Teaching From Recruiting to Career of the grant was to increase the number of science, technology (computer science specifically), engineering, and math (STEM) teachers produced by Boise State University to support high-need school districts.  The three main foci of the grant included recruitment and retention of teacher education candidates through the Summer Internship Program, retention in the teacher preparation program through the support of the Noyce Scholarship Program, and support for our new graduates through the Induction Support Program.

    The Summer Internship Program was designed to give students experiences in both formal and informal STEM learning settings during the summer. In addition to being paid, students also were supported through a collaborative seminar during their internship time. Throughout the life of the grant, 57 students were given the opportunity to participate in the Summer Internship Program. In addition to helping students explore and further deepen their interest in becoming teachers, the summer internships afforded students the opportunity to practice teaching skills they were learning in their education coursework. An added benefit of the summer internships has been the development of relationships between Boise State’s STEM teacher education program with a variety of non-profit community partners. Over the life of the grant, the Summer Internship Program has partnered with 12 organizations in the surrounding community, in addition to on-campus partnerships.

    One of the largest impacts of the grant comes from the Noyce Scholarship Program. Students selected as scholars received $10,000/year in scholarship support. Many positive outcomes have resulted from these scholarships. First, associating the scholarship opportunity with our teacher preparation program has been an excellent recruitment tool. When students hear about this opportunity, they are intrigued to learn more about our program, and several have indicated it was the reason they decided to pursue a STEM teaching certificate. Another outcome of the Noyce Scholarship Program has been that our scholars are able to focus on coursework rather than worrying about money and working too many hours (which over influences their ability to complete their degree). The average GPA of our Noyce Scholar graduates over the course of the grant was a 3.5. Finally, and most importantly, the Noyce Scholarship Program has helped to increase the number of STEM teachers in our area. Becoming a Noyce Scholar requires a commitment to teach since they are obligated to teach for one year for every $5000 they receive. Throughout the life of the grant, the grant resulted in 22 new STEM teachers, with 15 more teachers scheduled to graduate within the next 2 years. This is a total of 47 Noyce Scholars that are fulfilling STEM teaching positions in high-needs schools. These graduates are primarily dispersed throughout our state; many teaching in hard-to-fill positions in high needs rural schools.

    Finally, the NSF grant has supported our new teachers during their challenging first few years of teaching through the Induction Support Program. Our induction support involves a series of workshop seminars which include relevant and timely topics, as well as a strong community of practice. The first set of Noyce scholars graduated in spring 2015. In the fall of 2016, three graduates participated in the induction support program. We have continued the program for 3 years now, and we have been able to provide induction support to 16 graduates. The support included one credit and stipend for participation.Participants have communicated that the impact of this support has significant in helping them through their initial years of teaching.

    The intellectual merit of the program and its contribution to the knowledge base for teacher education comes from our understanding of how a continuum of support from internships to scholarships to induction support can be used to recruit, retain, and further develop high-quality STEM teachers.
